ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is both a survey of key early modern ethical texts and an in depth story about the emergence of the characteristically modern idea of obligation. I would definitely recommend it.
This was an excellent seminar. The professor is erudite, kind, and engaged. He was accommodating to non-philosophers on many levels.
I would recommending, but I would warn him/her that it's a very tough course.
Yes, I would recommend the class to another student. The material was intrinsically interesting and wonderfully presented.
This course was very much a survey course. I sometimes found it frustrating that so much reading was assigned and then only small bits were discussed.
This is a strong course that provides the material necessary to achieve a broad understanding of the history of modern ethics. I would recommend it to someone interested in that area.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It was really an introduction to most of the texts for me, but it really helped my research in giving me a better understanding of the history that gave rise to current moral thinking.

This course was a historical overview of leading figures in modern philosophy. It significantly deepened/broadened my knowledge of this period. This is only tangentially related to my field, but it added a valuable perspective.
Primary source readings of key texts in an important period in the history of ethics.
